content: The EPA believes there should be a higher rate of NSR permits for new or expanded facilities. The CAA requires preconstruction review and permits for major modifications or new sources of air pollution. States with EPA-approved SIPs must approve new construction or modifications to ensure compliance with NAAQS and PSD regulations. The NSR process is triggered for any new source potentially emitting 100 tons annually. The New Source Review (NSR) process is triggered for new sources potentially emitting 100 tons annually of any criteria air pollutant. NSR requirements depend on whether the sources are subject to Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) or non-attainment provisions. PSD sources must install Best Available Control Technology (BACT), while non-attainment sources must install Lowest Achievable Emission Rate (LAER) and obtain offsets. Both BACT and LAER must be at least as stringent as federal standards. The New Source Review (NSR) process requires new sources emitting 100 tons annually of any criteria air pollutant to comply with either Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) or non-attainment provisions. PSD sources must use Best Available Control Technology (BACT), while non-attainment sources must use Lowest Achievable Emission Rate (LAER) and obtain offsets. Both BACT and LAER must meet or exceed federal standards. Despite the broad coverage of NSR, few preconstruction permits have been issued to coal-fired power plants. The lack of permits is not surprising given the steady capacity of coal-fired electric generating facilities in the US. However, while there was a 4.7 million ton reduction in SO2 emissions by 1995, overall emissions only decreased by about 3.6 million tons. Similarly, a 0.4 million ton reduction in NOx emissions by 1996 was offset by an overall reduction of only about 0.1 million tons. This slippage is attributed to the continuing operation of existing coal-fired facilities, despite a lack of new plant construction.
